citations.narrative:
***It was late afternoon when USDA conducted the inspection. Upon entering the shelter where the fox enclosures are
located, USDA observed that the water buckets and/or bottles in all but one of the enclosures contained no water. USDA
watched observed while water was provided to three of the enclosures. In the first enclosure the fox was observed
immediately attempting to drink from the stream of water as it was being poured into the bucket with a watering can.
While the attendant went to refill the watering can, USDA observed the fox in an adjacent enclosure anxiously biting at the
water bottle until it became detached and fell to the ground. After water was added to a bucket in another enclosure
USDA observed a fox circling the water bucket that was too tall, trying to find a way to access the water. The foxes'
immediate attempt to drink when water was provided indicates the foxes were thirsty. Insufficient provision of water may
lead to dehydration, poor health and possibly death. When water is not accessible to animals at all times it must be
provided as often as necessary to provide for their health and wellbeing. Correct immediately.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Jeffrey Shepherd, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALISTEnd Section

narrative:
3.130  Direct
   
Watering. 
***It was late afternoon when USDA conducted the inspection. Upon entering the shelter where the fox enclosures are 
located, USDA observed that the water buckets and/or bottles in all but one of the enclosures contained no water.  USDA 
watched observed while water was provided to three of the enclosures.  In the first enclosure the fox was observed 
immediately attempting to drink from the stream of water as it was being poured into the bucket with a watering can.  
While the attendant went to refill the watering can, USDA observed the fox in an adjacent enclosure anxiously biting at the 
water bottle until it became detached and fell to the ground.  After water was added to a bucket in another enclosure 
USDA observed a fox circling the water bucket that was too tall, trying to find a way to access the water.  The foxes' 
immediate attempt to drink when water was provided indicates the foxes were thirsty.  Insufficient provision of water may 
lead to dehydration, poor health and possibly death.  When water is not accessible to animals at all times it must be 
provided as often as necessary  to provide for their health and wellbeing.   Correct immediately. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Jeffrey Shepherd, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALISTEnd Section

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)

species.scientific: Canis lupus X C. l. familiaris
